transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Good morning, Diane. Thanks so much for taking the time to speak with me today. My name is Sarah, and I'm part of the product development team here at iRobot. We really value customer feedback, especially detailed insights like the review you recently left for your Roomba 694. It helps us understand how our products are being used in real-world scenarios and where we can improve.

transcript.speaker: **Diane
transcript.text: ** Good morning, Sarah. No problem at all. Happy to help. I appreciate you reaching out; it's good to know my feedback is actually being heard.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Absolutely. We really do listen. To start, could you tell me a bit more about what initially led you to purchase the Roomba 694? What specific problem were you hoping it would solve for you and your family?

transcript.speaker: **Diane
transcript.text: ** Hmm, well, it was about six months ago. My husband and I were just… drowning in dog hair, honestly. We have a Labrador, and with two toddlers also in the mix, our main floor just constantly had crumbs and fur tumbleweeds. It felt like I was vacuuming manually every single day, and frankly, as a manager with a pretty demanding job, I just didn't have the time or energy for it. The idea of a robot vacuum, specifically a Roomba because of the brand recognition, seemed like a perfect solution to just take that daily chore off my plate. I imagined it being this truly autonomous, "set it and forget it" kind of helper.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That makes perfect sense. It sounds like you were really looking for something to ease that daily burden. And thinking back, did you consider any other robot vacuum models or even other brands before landing on the 694? What made you choose this particular one?

transcript.speaker: **Diane
transcript.text: ** We did look around a bit, but honestly, the 694 felt like a good entry point. It had the Wi-Fi connectivity, which was a must for me – the idea of scheduling it from my phone was super appealing. Other models seemed significantly more expensive, and for what I thought I needed, the 694 seemed like a good balance of features and price. I figured, "It's a Roomba, it'll handle the basics."

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** So, the Wi-Fi and scheduling were big draws, and the price point seemed right for what you were anticipating. Once you had it home and started using it, what were your initial impressions? What immediately stood out as positive?

transcript.speaker: **Diane
transcript.text: ** Oh, definitely the pet hair pickup. That was immediate and impressive. Within the first few days, I noticed a huge difference in the amount of dog hair. It really *does* get it, especially on our laminate floors. And the daily crumbs from the kids? Gone. My floors genuinely looked and felt cleaner, and that initial relief was huge. Plus, the app interface is quite user-friendly, and emptying the bin is truly a breeze, which is important when it's full of fur every day.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That's great to hear, especially about the pet hair and the ease of emptying the bin. Those are key features for many of our customers. You mentioned in your review that it's a "helpful assistant" but not a "set it and forget it" solution. Could you elaborate on where that "set it and forget it" ideal starts to fall short for you?

transcript.speaker: **Diane
transcript.text: ** Mmm, yeah, that's where the frustration really sets in. The biggest thing, by far, is the navigation. It’s just so… random. It bumps into things, changes direction, and just wanders around. There's no mapping, no logic to its path. I’ve watched it spend ten minutes cleaning the same two square feet of floor while completely ignoring a clearly dirty patch just a few feet away. It's like it has cleaning ADHD, you know? It just circles and circles.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** I understand completely. The "bump and go" navigation can definitely lead to a perceived inefficiency. How does that impact your daily routine? Does it mean you have to intervene often, or do you just accept that some spots might be missed?

transcript.speaker: **Diane
transcript.text: ** Both, really. It means I can never truly rely on it for a *comprehensive* clean. It’s purely for surface maintenance, like keeping the worst of the fur and crumbs at bay. But it also leads directly into the second huge issue: it gets stuck. All the time. With kids and a dog, there are always rogue toys, a charging cable, or even the fringe on our living room rug. We try our best to "Roomba-proof" the house before each run, but without fail, it gets trapped somewhere.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** So, even with pre-cleaning, you're still regularly rescuing it. How frequently would you say you have to intervene during a typical cleaning cycle?

transcript.speaker: **Diane
transcript.text: ** Ugh, it varies, but honestly, at least once a run, sometimes two or three times. The app notification is helpful, sure, but it means what should be an autonomous process suddenly requires *my* direct involvement. I'm usually at work or picking up the kids, and I get a notification, then I have to remember to free it when I get home. It just adds another item to my mental to-do list, which defeats the whole purpose of buying it to save time and mental load.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That completely diminishes the convenience factor you were looking for. Beyond the navigation and getting stuck, you also mentioned the brushes needing frequent cleaning and the noise level. Could you expand on those?

transcript.speaker: **Diane
transcript.text: ** The brushes are definitely a chore. With the Labrador's shedding, plus my own long hair, they get tangled incredibly quickly. It's kind of a messy, fiddly job to pull all that hair out. It doesn't take *ages*, but it's another one of those things that chips away at the "easy" factor. And the noise... it's not like a jet engine, but it's loud enough that we can't run it when the kids are napping or if we're trying to watch TV or have a conversation in the main living area. We pretty much have to time its runs for when no one is home or we're all in a different part of the house.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That's really valuable feedback. So, it sounds like the "automation" aspect is significantly compromised by these interventions and limitations. Given all these points, how do you see the Roomba 694 fitting into your overall cleaning routine now, compared to how you envisioned it originally?

transcript.speaker: **Diane
transcript.text: ** Well, it definitely hasn't replaced manual vacuuming entirely. I still have to pull out our upright vacuum once a week or every ten days for a proper, deep clean, especially in the corners and under furniture where the Roomba just can't get or simply misses. Before, I was doing a light manual vacuum every day or two. Now, the Roomba does the daily maintenance, which *does* reduce the frequency of the full manual vacuum. So, it's a helpful *supplement*, but not a replacement. It’s more like... a really diligent, but slightly absent-minded, intern.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** *chuckles lightly* That's a great analogy. So, when you think about the price you paid for the 694, do you feel you've gotten adequate value for your investment, considering its strengths and weaknesses?

transcript.speaker: **Diane
transcript.text: ** Hmm, that's a tough one. For the daily pet hair control and the scheduling feature, yes, it's worth it. It genuinely helps keep the house from becoming a fur ball. But for what I *hoped* it would be – a truly autonomous cleaner that would free up significant time – no, not entirely. I mean, it's a good entry-level device, but I probably would have paid more for one with better navigation and obstacle avoidance if I had known how much of a pain point those would be.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That insight into value perception is very helpful. If you were talking to a friend or colleague, who would you recommend the Roomba 694 to, and who would you advise against it for?

transcript.speaker: **Diane
transcript.text: ** I'd recommend it to someone who has *only* hard floors, maybe a small apartment, with pets, and who just needs basic, daily surface cleaning, and is willing to occasionally babysit it. Someone who isn't expecting a full, deep clean, and maybe doesn't have a lot of random obstacles around. I definitely *wouldn't* recommend it to someone like me, who has kids, varying floor types including rugs with fringe, and really needs a truly smart, hands-off solution. Or someone with a large, complex layout.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That distinction is really clear. Thinking about those areas for improvement – the navigation, getting stuck, brush cleaning, noise – if you could suggest one or two key enhancements for a future Roomba model, especially one at a similar or slightly higher price point, what would they be?

transcript.speaker: **Diane
transcript.text: ** Hands down, mapping. Even if it's a basic form of mapping, so it knows where it's been and where it needs to go. That would solve the inefficiency and the missed spots. And tied to that, better obstacle avoidance. Not necessarily full AI, but something that can "see" a power cord or a toy before it gets tangled in it. If it had those two things, I would be a much happier customer, and I wouldn't mind paying a bit more for that level of intelligence. Oh, and maybe self-cleaning brushes that are actually effective!

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** Mapping and improved obstacle avoidance are definitely areas we're constantly working on and getting a lot of feedback about. Just one last question, Diane. If a competitor were to offer a robot vacuum with significantly better navigation and obstacle avoidance, let's say at a slightly higher price point than your current 694, what would be the likelihood of you switching brands?

transcript.speaker: **Diane
transcript.text: ** Oh, definitely very high. Almost certain, actually. If I could get a robot vacuum that actually mapped my home, avoided getting stuck consistently, and delivered a truly comprehensive clean without me having to intervene, I would switch in a heartbeat. The time savings and the reduced mental burden would be well worth a higher price. The whole point for me was to automate, not to trade one chore for another.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** That's incredibly clear and valuable feedback, Diane. Thank you so much for your honesty and for sharing such detailed insights. It gives us a lot to consider as we continue to develop and refine our products. Before we wrap up, on a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being "extremely dissatisfied" and 10 being "extremely satisfied," what would be your overall satisfaction rating for your Roomba 694 today?

transcript.speaker: **Diane
transcript.text: ** Hmm, with all the pros and cons... I'd probably still give it a 6. It does a core job well, and it's better than nothing, but it falls short of its full potential and my initial expectations.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** A 6. Okay, thank you for that. We truly appreciate you sharing your experience, Diane. Is there anything else you'd like to add before we conclude?

transcript.speaker: **Diane
transcript.text: ** I don't think so, Sarah. Just that I really hope these improvements are in the pipeline. I *want* to love Roomba, and I think the core idea is brilliant.

transcript.speaker: **Sarah
transcript.text: ** We hear you loud and clear. Thanks again for your time, Diane. Have a wonderful rest of your day.

transcript.speaker: **Diane
transcript.text: ** You too, Sarah. Bye.
